statement:
Let $f:[a,b]\to{\mathbb{R}}$ be a real-valued continuous function on
$[a,b]$, which is differentiable on $(a,b)$, differentiable from the
right at $a$, and differentiable from the left at $b$. Then $f'$ the
intermediate value theorem: for every $t$ between $f'_{+}(a)$ and
$f'_{-}(b)$, there is some $x\in [a,b]$ such that $f'(x)=t$.

Note that when $f$ is continuously differentiable ($f\in C^1([a,b])$),
this is trivially true *by* the intermediate value theorem. But even
when $f'$ is *not* continuous, Darboux’s theorem places a severe
restriction on what it can be.
names: intermediate value property of the derivative
